body_text.text: Introduction

For many years, social scientists the world over have been using large-scale, longitudinal datasets that are available to them to answer research-driven questions using evidencebased analyses. This was first started in 1968 on a large scale with the American Panel Study of Income Dynamics (PSID), housed at the University of Michigan. Indeed, this dataset continues to provide invaluable data on generations of individuals in households concerning topics, such as educational attainment, housing situations and income and employment dynamics, and was described in detail by Hill (1991).

Following the US lead, in 1984 the German Socio-Economic Panel Study (SOEP) was established at the German Institute for Economic Research in Berlin, Germany. It built upon many ideas that had been established in the American PSID and introduced a hierarchical data structure to manage the complicated data at different levels, such as person, household, roster and sampled and over time. This structure is documented in Haisken-DeNew and Frick (2005). In 1991, the British Household Panel Study (BHPS) was introduced to cover the population of Great Britain. Taylor et al. (2010) document this study in many hundreds of pages of detailed information.

Following the tradition of their American, German and British counterparts, in 2001 the Australian household panel dataset, Household, Income and Labour Dynamics in Australia (HILDA) Survey, was released for the first time for academic and government use. Watson and Wooden (2002) and Wooden, Freidin and Watson (2002) document this first release. From the PSID to the HILDA Survey, the content of longitudinal datasets remained largely similar, although the data structure and variable naming schemes in which the data were stored could not be more heterogeneous between datasets.

The key to retrieving data from a dataset is to understand the data file and variable naming scheme. The PSID system used a simple variable-naming scheme, in which variables were sequentially numbered (that is, v1 followed by v2 and v3). This reached a limit in 1993 with the variable v23363 and, in 1994, the 'early release' (er) files started a new variable name scheme with er2001, which was followed by er2002 and so on. Due to the sequential naming of the variables, a range of variables was found in the family file for 1968, another range of variables for 1969 and so on. However, one had no way of knowing the variable name of another year, given the variable name of a particular year. When the German SOEP addressed the issue of variable names, it followed the hierarchical structure of the data. Thus, the variable name ap3301 referred to the 'a' wave (1984), 'p' at the person level and the 33rd question of the person questionnaire, but specifically the first part of that multi-part question. However, there was no guarantee that the next year would follow suit in the variable naming. The BHPS went first into 'speaking variable names', in which the variable names no longer identified the order of the variable in a dataset, but rather the content and the year in which this content was collected. For instance, the variable rmovjb asked in the 'r' wave refers to 'moved for employment reasons'.

The Australian HILDA Survey follows the scheme outlined by the BHPS to a large extent and prefaces every single variable with a twoletter category code. For instance, 'ws' refers to 'wages and salaries'. The variable jwscmg asked in the 'j' wave (or 2010) deals with wages and salaries (ws) but specifically addresses 'Main job, current weekly gross wages & salary'. Indeed, the same variable 1 year previously ('i' wave) is called deterministically iwscmg. By adding a wave indicator, a broad category indicator and 'speaking names', the HILDA Survey's variable names are moderately identifiable in content, even if one has never seen the specific question or questionnaire before. Clearly, data structure and variable-naming schemes have evolved over time.

However, no previous dataset has changed its data structures or naming schemes to keep up with international longitudinal dataset 'best practice'. If one could have a tool to find the common denominators of the various panel datasets and create a simple, yet effective, manner of dealing with all datasets in the same way, then this would be useful to researchers of all datasets, especially those interested in comparative research. Indeed, the creators of the Cross-National Equivalent File, run out of Cornell University, New York, were faced immediately with this issue, as they attempted to deal with data from the American PSID, German SOEP, British BHPS and Australian HILDA Survey. The common redefining of variable names and content is described in Frick et al. (2007).

Although the Australian HILDA Survey was the first large-scale, longitudinal dataset to establish itself in Australia, there are now many more datasets, as described in Table 1, addressing populations such as children in Australia, Aboriginal children, youths, recent immigrants, doctors and the homeless. All of the datasets have different instruments or questionnaires, different data structures and variable-naming schemes and little has changed since Haisken-DeNew (2001). Thus, left alone, each dataset would require substantial investment in understanding the dataset before one could start to do any analyses.

One software solution to the many of the issues raised here is a tool called 'PanelWhiz' <http://www.panelwhiz.com>, which is written in and for the statistical package called Stata <http://www.stata.com>. For the German SOEP, its functionality is summarised in Haisken-DeNew and Hahn (2010). PanelWhiz was initially developed to deal specifically with the complexity of the German SOEP structure on variable naming, but has since expanded to cover all of the world's major household panel datasets.

PanelWhiz is a graphical user interface that allows users to extract data from known datasets in a controlled manner, without having to write data extraction code oneself. The structure of the data is in fact embedded into the data itself and is called up and read by PanelWhiz to allow it to use this structure automatically, without the user having to delve further in the data structure. In terms of the amount of Stata programming code, it is the largest-ever user-written collection of add-ons for Stata. PanelWhiz provides in Stata an analogous platform to what the Integrated Public Use Microdata Series (for more information, see Minnesota Population Center 2001) does at the browser level. This article outlines the features of PanelWhiz in conjunction with Australian datasets that are listed in Table 1.
Issues of Structure in Australian Panel Data

body_text.section: Issues of Structure in Australian Panel Data
body_text.text: The Australian HILDA Survey, in its simplest version, contains one single 'combined' file per wave or year, starting in 2001, such that any household-level information has been added to every person in that household. In addition, there is a master file which contains entries for each person who has ever entered into the HILDA Survey sample. The master file allows one to use this as a starting point and define the sample immediately (that is, a sample of only men, from 2001 to 2004). The (longitudinal) person identifier xwaveid is consistent over time and data files. The HILDA Survey, on the other hand, has no concept of a longitudinal household. All persons aged 15 and over are interviewed directly. Longitudinal identifiers for spouses, mothers, fathers etc. are also available, such that one could retrieve data on individual wages and of the spouse and use the variables in the same regression. See Wooden and Watson (2007) and Wooden, Freidin and Watson (2002) for more information. Following this structure, the dataset 'Medicine in Australia: Balancing Employment and Life' (MABEL), labour market survey of doctors, also uses a longitudinal person identifier xwaveid and also a one-letter wave indicator and a two-letter classification scheme for each variable. Thus, the variable ajshw refers to the 'a' wave (2008) and 'js' to 'job satisfaction' and the remaining 'hw' refers to 'hours of work'. This variable is called bjshw in the following wave and so on. See Joyce et al. (2010) and Yan et al. (2011) for an overview.

body_text.section: Issues of Structure in Australian Panel Data
body_text.text: The Longitudinal Survey of Australian Children (LSAC) is a survey that started in 2004 and contains two cohorts of children: the (K) kids cohort of 4-to 5-year olds and the (B) 0-to 1-year-old baby cohort. The children are followed generally every year, along with detailed information on the mother, father or other guardians, as outlined in Commonwealth of Australia (2012b). The major identifiers are hicid: household identification number, the cohort and the wave. The focus is on the study child (SC) in a particular family, in which Parent 1 (P1) and Parent 2 (P2) are identified. Parents living elsewhere (PLEs) are also identified. In the LSAC, the variable names start with the wave letter (a-d), use a one-or two-letter code to reflect the topic area, such as 'LC' for 'Learning and cognition outcomes', followed by a question or sub-question number. There are physically separate data files for each cohort and year. See also Gray and Smart (2009) for more detailed information.

body_text.section: Issues of Structure in Australian Panel Data
body_text.text: In a similar manner, the Longitudinal Survey of Indigenous Children (LSIC) addresses indigenous children, with an albeit smaller sample of under 2,000 children, but also focusing on two cohorts: the (K) kids cohort of 3.5-to 4.5-year olds and the (B) 16-to 18month-old baby cohort. The data use the xwaveid and wave to identify the children over time and also focus on the study child (SC) as in the LSAC. Mullan and Redmond (2012) provide a scientific overview of the LSIC, while Commonwealth of Australia (2012a) outlines the data content and reports some basic findings.

body_text.section: Issues of Structure in Australian Panel Data
body_text.text: The Consumer Attitudes, Sentiments & Expectations in Australia (CASiE) is an exceptional dataset, in that it is not a longitudinal dataset like the HILDA Survey, but rather is a series of repeated cross-sections, and has been available-monthly-since 1995, consisting of approximately 1,200 respondents every month. Thus, if one were interested in general movements from month to month, this dataset is of particular interest. Men and women aged from 16 to 65 years are asked primarily questions on economic expectations and consumer sentiment. Each respondent is characterised by gender, age, occupation, education, political party preference, home ownership, household income and post-code, in addition to many other time-changing indicators. The file structure has one file per year, with all 12 months of a year put into the one file.

body_text.section: Issues of Structure in Australian Panel Data
body_text.text: Needless to say, there are very differing file structures and relational dependencies between files and datasets. The HILDA Survey, MABEL, LSAC, LSIC and CASiE are all similar in many dimensions, yet different enough to pose a challenge even for hardened empirical economists.
Common Interface for Australian Data

The obvious advantage of using PanelWhiz is the power of the common interface. Every survey supported by PanelWhiz, regardless of original structure, is integrated into the system in a similar manner. The entire dataset is scanned for critical pieces of information: (i) which physical data files belong together in a data year; (ii) variable names and how they correspond to each other over time; and (iii) keywords associated with variable labels.

In contrast to standard statistical software, one does not open a data file and select one single variable, but rather one can select an entire vector of variables belonging to each other. As all words used in variable labels are scanned, one can compile a total list of all used words from the labels and create an index of keywords or dictionary, linking each known keyword to a particular variable, which in turn can be related to an entire vector of variables which belong together over time.°C

To start off, one selects the dataset of interest (in this case, HILDA Survey). Assuming that one were to start a data project from scratch, as in Figure 1, one would first be interested in opening either a specific wave or a keyword list. Here, we will examine a specific wave. The HILDA Survey contains information from 2001 to 2011, and correspondingly, there are clickable links for each year's wave. A browse page is created when clicking on a year. However, many datasets contain thousands of variables, making the creation of browse pages a relatively slow process. PanelWhiz creates a browse page once when needed, and if the page already exists, PanelWhiz simply uses it. The browse page is valid for a given distribution of data. It may become necessary to delete and recreate the browse pages if, for instance, there is a new release or revised version of the data.

In Figure 1, we select the 2010 wave [j -2010]. In the HILDA Survey, for the 'j' wave (or 2010), the respondent is asked whether he has a long-term health condition, as indicated by the variable jhelth in Figure 2. However, one can simply click on the 'item' called helth, which would represent all the years' information from wave 'a' to wave 'k'.

If one were to click on 'N' (that is, notes), one would see the following vector of variables in Figure 3, all associated with the item called 'helth'. Clicking on 'S' would produce summary statistics and 'T' would produce tabulations.

All words used in item labels become part of the keyword dictionary and can be searched. Thus, searching or clicking on the word 'unable' would produce output like in Figure 4. PanelWhiz would list all items having the word 'unable' in the item label. Items could then be immediately selected, regardless of the wave or year.
After having selected several items and having stored the PanelWhiz project under a name, such as 'myproject', the Project Page would look something like in Figure 5.

The items selected would be sorted by their categories, such as 'AN' for 'Ancestry'. Adding any new items to the project would create additional entries in the Project Page. Here, in this particular view of the Project Page, we see  By clicking on 'Retrieval', the data retrieval is started. File by file, the data files are opened, the selected variables are kept and possibly renamed, sub-sets of the files are stored in temporary files and then they are pieced together to create one rectangularised file in Stata 'long' format (observations stacked on each other, year by year).
Conclusions

PanelWhiz is a tool written entirely in Stata's own programming language, which facilitates easy data extraction using a graphical user interface. Users are not required to write data retrieval programs, as PanelWhiz generates and runs extraction code on the fly, based on the variables selected. Due to its common interface and implementation for many datasets, it is useful for international comparative work and allows for an easy introduction to a new dataset for first-time users. As the data retrievals are standardised and used by many researchers, the chance of mistakes in the initial data-creation phase of any research is virtually reduced to zero. Updates to PanelWhiz are pushed to users and are installed in the same manner as Stata itself. PanelWhiz currently has more than 300 users and currently supports international datasets such as the German SOEP, the British BHPS (or its successor, the UK Understanding Society study), the American PSID and Current Population Survey-National Bureau of Economic Research, the American Survey of Income and Program Participation, the South African National Income Dynamics Study, in addition to the HILDA Survey, MABEL, LSAC, LSIC and CASiE. PanelWhiz runs in Windows, Mac and Linux, but needs at least Stata SE/MP 11 or later to run.
